head.title: Early Birds Get the Best Spot

hedline.hl1: Early Birds Get the Best Spot

abstract.p: Orchard Beach, Bronx, picnicker comments on arriving early July 4 to claim best spot (M)

block.p: At 10 a.m. yesterday, lifeguards on the 14 stands at Orchard Beach in the Bronx went on duty. They stood and blew their whistles in unison, and crowds of children dashed into the water.

At 10 a.m. yesterday, lifeguards on the 14 stands at Orchard Beach in the Bronx went on duty. They stood and blew their whistles in unison, and crowds of children dashed into the water.
At a grassy picnic area next to the beach's parking lot, Jose Urbina concentrated on the steaks and chicken he was grilling for his friends and family.

Mr. Urbina likes to spend the Fourth of July at this picnic area celebrating his dual heritage with other Puerto Ricans. So to secure a good spot, he and his group left Hoboken at 4 a.m. and took the train to Manhattan. They took two more trains and a bus to arrive at Orchard Beach at 6:30. They set up camp under the oak trees and lit the barbecue coals by 7. By 8, the steaks were cooked medium-well, the rice and beans and pasteles were served and bottles of Heineken were pulled from the cooler.
Mr. Urbina said he used to run his own barbershop near San Juan and was earning less now, working in a Jersey City shop. But he prefers America's diverse population.

''There, you just see Puerto Ricans,'' he said, as ''La Libertad,'' a song by the famous salsa singer Frankie Ruiz, blasted from a huge radio on his picnic table. ''Here, you have all types of people: black, Indian, Chinese. That's important.''
